results.title: Torpedo bombers = Torpedonostsy
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Films of the great victory 1941-1945”.
By interspersing historical footage with fictional narrative, this film attempts to present the precarious fighting conditions for WW2 Russian bomber pilots. The filmmaker ably captures the taxing environment in which battles were conducted and the constant danger to those serving in the armed forces. It also depicts the fraught personal lives of the pilots, under strain from wartime conditions. Based on the stories by Yuri German.

results.title: Toronto: boom town
results.creator_credit: Sydney Newman, Leslie McFarlane and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Canada carries on”
A contrast between the sedate Toronto, Canada, of half a century ago and the thriving, expanding metropolis of today

results.title: Toronto Symphony No. 2
results.creator_credit: Alan Field, ONF | NFB and Julian Roffman
results.brief_description: The third movement of Tchaikovsky’s Sixth Symphony in B minor, played by the Toronto Symphony Orchestra under the direction of its conductor Sir Ernest McMillan. The camera picks out different sections of the orchestra, and some well-known musicians.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alan Field, ONF | NFB and Julian Roffman

results.title: Toronto Symphony No. 1
results.creator_credit: Alan Field, ONF | NFB and Julian Roffman
results.brief_description: The Toronto Symphony Orchestra is shown playing three contemporary works: “Jamaican Rhumba” by the Australian, Arthur Benjamin; Sir Ernest MacMillan’s “A St. Malo”, a sketch for strings; and, finally, the Overture to the opera, “Colas Breugnon” by Dimitri Kabalevskv.

results.title: Toronto jazz
results.creator_credit: Roman Kroitor, Don Owen and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Toronto is regarded as the third largest jazz centre in North America. This film features a cross-section of jazz bands of that city: the Lenny Breau Trio, the Don Thompson Quintet and the Alf Jones Quartet. Their styles show creative self-expression, hard work, and improvisation.

results.title: Torn curtain
results.brief_description: Hitchcock’s 50th film, set during the Cold War, repeats his successful espionage-thriller theme. Paul Newman portrays American nuclear physicist Michael Armstrong who fakes defection to East Germany in order to obtain Communist defence secrets. His fiance and assistant, Sarah Sherman (Julie Andrews) aroused by Armstrong’s suspicious behaviour yet unaware of his intentions, follows him behind the iron curtain. When she realises her fiance’s intentions, she joins him in his effort to obtain secret information and return safely to the United States. Also stars Lila Kedrova, Hansjoerg Felmy, David Opatoshu, and Ludwig Donath. Cinematography by John F. Warren. Written by Brian Moore. Music by John Addison.

results.title: Torment = L' Enfer
results.creator_credit: Marin Karmitz, MK2 Productions, S A CED Productions, France 3 Cinema, Cinemanuel and Claude Chabrol
results.brief_description: This highly successful thriller from one of France’s most renowned and revered directors is set in the countryside of South western France. Hoteliers Nelly (Emmanuel Beart) and Paul (Francois Cluzet) have a marriage made in heaven. Paul is proud of his exceptionally beautiful wife, and Nelly blossoms, radiating a heady mix of innocence and sexuality that is openly admired by their male customers. However, their happiness is threatened when Paul begins to spy on his wife and becomes convinced of her infidelity. His obsessive jealousy turns to anger, which erupts in a cruel and violent climax. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Torment = Hets
results.brief_description: The storyline of this film, although simple and straightforward, reveals a beautifully observed and incise psychological drama, written by Ingmar Bergman when he was 26 years old. It is the tale of sadistic teacher in a cheerless and strict school who takes delight in exercising his reign of terror over his Latin classes. One evening as final examination time approaches, one of his students, Jan-Erik, goes to the aid of Bertha, the newsagents assistant who is drunk in the street. They become lovers, but Jan-Erik is aware of the presence of another man in her life who frightens her. He finds Bertha dead in her room and on finding the teacher in her hallway discovers he is the other man. The teacher is arrested, but is released when the cause of her death is revealed as heart failure coupled with malnutrition. Following a confrontation with the teacher in the headmasters study, Jan-Erik is expelled from school, but when the headmaster becomes aware of the teachers tyrannical methods, the boy is reinstated and the teacher punished for his crimes.

results.title: Tora! tora! tora!
results.creator_credit: Elmo Williams, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Richard Fleischer, Toshio Masuda and Kinji Fukasaku
results.brief_description: Tora! Tora! Tora! was an epic and expensive production that attempted to present realistically the battle for Pearl Harbour and the ensuing warring between the American and Japanese armies in World War II. In a unique approach, the battle is presented from both sides, rejecting traditional notions of one-sided jingoistic storytelling, typical of many war films from the 50s and 60s. For the Japanese section directors Toshio Masuda and Kinji Fukasaku pay close attention to the military manoeuvring and blunders of the campaign as well as the infighting and personal clashes within the high command. For the American section, the army is depicted as unsuspecting of an attack of this scale, hampered by limited technology and a lack of foresight. Exciting battle sequences and detailed inner-sanctum decision making within both sides of the battle make “Tora! Tora! Tora!” an interesting war movie that is not simplistic in its politics and is effective in its recreation of a historically significant event. Cast includes Martin Balsam, So Yamamura, Joseph Cotton, Tatsuya Mihashi, E.G. Marshall, James Whitemore, Takahiro Tamura, Eijiro Tono, Jason Robards.

results.title: Tor Schwanck: gold and silversmith
results.creator_credit: Nina Syme, Terry McMahon and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Craft as a Livelihood”
Metal-work has been in Tor Schwanck’s family since the 15th century. He is an artisan trained in all aspects of metal-work. Schwanck uses non-precious metals as well as gold and silver. All the designs are originals, and he tours, exhibits and receives commissions for his work.
